<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 171, 291]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 415, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 368, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 396, 386, 407]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 422, 718, 434]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 437, 325, 448]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 607, 463]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 465, 598, 476]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 479, 384, 490]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 505, 256, 516]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 519, 764, 531]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 603, 556]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 757, 571]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 723, 905, 848]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 95, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 875, 122]]<|/det|>
A fairground ride carries passengers in chairs which are attached by metal rods to a rotating central pole, as shown in Fig 1.1. When the pole rotates with angular velocity \(\omega\) , the rods make an angle \(\theta\) to the vertical.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 140, 740, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 460, 505, 477]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 491, 575, 507]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\cos \theta\) is inversely proportional to \(\omega^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 521, 875, 568]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment, using a small object to represent an occupied chair, to test the relationship between \(\theta\) and \(\omega\). You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 144, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 405, 599]]<|/det|>
the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 615, 156, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 615, 415, 630]]<|/det|>
the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 645, 146, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 645, 351, 661]]<|/det|>
the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 676, 156, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 676, 355, 692]]<|/det|>
the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 707, 146, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 442, 723]]<|/det|>
the safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 723, 875, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 875, 108]]<|/det|>
A current-carrying wire is clamped at each end, as shown in Fig 2.1. A student investigates how the deflection \(y\) at the centre of the wire varies with the current \(I\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 123, 820, 406]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 428, 509, 445]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 514, 476]]<|/det|>
For different currents, the deflection is recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 660, 650, 676]]<|/det|>
<pre>Question 2 continues on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 566, 90]]<|/det|> 
It is suggested that \(y\) and \(I\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 103, 510, 121]]<|/det|>

\[y = sI^r\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 355, 151]]<|/det|>

where \(r\) and \(s\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 166, 146, 184]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 875, 199]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of lg \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against lg \(I\) on the \(x\)-axis. Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept in terms of \(r\) and \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 298, 875, 314]]<|/det|>

gradient = ............................................................


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 330, 875, 345]]<|/det|>

y-intercept = ............................................................


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 346, 875, 363]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 376, 148, 394]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 376, 470, 393]]<|/det|>
